HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Felipa

texts.es:
La señora Felipa es socia del  Banco Comunal “Manuela de Hoy II”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad de Camicachi de el distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 42 años de edad, estado civil casada y madre de 4 hijos, Felipa no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar, ella  vive en la comunidad de segundo Camicachi.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace años, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que lo utilizo en la compra de ganado menor. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 2500.00 Nuevos soles, para invertirlo en la compra ganado menor ovino, además parte del dinero será utilizado en su negocio de venta de comida.

Su deseo es continuar trabajando para ayudar a sus hijos menores.

A ella le gustan los ahorros y las facilidades en los pagos.
texts.en:
Felipa is a member of the Manuela de Hoy II Community bank, which is located in the Camicachi community, Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department. She is 42, married, and she has four children. Felipa did not have the opportunity to get an education. She lives in the community of Segundo Camicachi. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for years. She used her initial loan for 300 PEN to buy small livestock. She now needs a loan for 2,500 PEN to buy sheep. Also, part of the money will be used in her food selling business. Her wish is to keep working and to help her younger children. She likes the savings and the ease of the payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sheep

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manuela D. Hoy II”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad D. Camicachi D. el distrito D. Ilave, Provincia D. El Collao, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 42 años D. edad, estado civil casada y madre D. 6 hijos y es iletrada, vive en sector Foraquita. 

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 4 meses,  con un préstamo inicial D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles  para la compra D. ganado menor. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 1200.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra D. ganado vacuno que luego del engorD. los venderá en las ferias D. la zona.

Su deseo seguir trabajando para ayudar a su familia.

A ella le gustan las facilidades D. los préstamos.
texts.en:
Juana belongs to the communal bank “Manuela D. Hoy II” which is located in the community of Camicachi in the Olave district, a part of the El Collao province in the departament of Puno. She is 42 years old, married and the mother of 6 children. She is illiterate and lives in the Foraquita sector. She has worked with the field partner Manuela Ramos for 4 months, taking out an initial loan of 500.00 nuevos soles which she used to buy small livestock. At the moment she requires a loan of 1200.00 nuevos soles to buy cattle which she will fatten up to sell in the markets in the area. Her desire is to continue working to help her family. She likes the ease of access to the loans with Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mr. Chantha N., aged 28, and his wife, Mrs. Savoeun Hean, aged 35, have been married since 2000 and have one son and one daughter. Chantha also has his parents living with him. The family lives in a suburb about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Chantha has been a construction worker for 10 years, while his wife has been a garment factory worker for 15 years. Chantha doesn’t have his own transport, so is requesting his first loan of $600 USD to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work

loans.name: Teth

texts.en: Teth S., 41, has five children, most of whom work at a water company. Her husband is a domestic fisherman and a casual worker. Teth has many different jobs. She raises female ducks to sell the eggs, and raises pigs for slaughter. In addition, she always cultivates a rice crop during the farming season. Teth operates her businesses very well. Recently, her stock of animal food has become exhausted; she wants to resupply and is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, HKL, to purchase more food to continue feeding her animals.

loans.use: To purchase more food to continue feeding her animals

loans.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Mrs. Kosal C., age 39, and her husband, Mr. Bunmeng Chheang, age 43, have been married for 15 years. They just have one daughter who attends school. The family lives on an island in Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Kosal has been working for a company that produces mild for 10 years. Mr. Bunmeng Chheang is a motor taxi driver. He drives in Phnom Penh City. The couple is in the process of building their new house, but they lack some money to finish it. So, Kosal is applying for her first loan of $500 to finish her house building.

loans.use: To finish her house building.

loans.name: Maselina

texts.en:
Maselina T. is a 32-year-old woman living in the town of Faala 2. She is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Maselina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Maselina has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 600 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Maselina joined Kiva partner, SPBD, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maselina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Maselina is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. The loan will be her second from SPBD. Maselina plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About SPBD
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Choet

texts.en: S. was born in 1964; she is a married woman and blessed with seven children. Three of them are married and the rest attend in the local public school. Her husband's name is Phorn, 47, and he carves small piece of wood from the forest for a profit. S. has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. She raises pig by using the leftover of her distilling wine. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for S. and her family, S. has requested a loan to buy additional piglets to raise for sale during the period when pork is commanding the highest price.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy S. is from the village of Gingoog, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Juvy owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Juvy has been engaged in her business for over 16 years.

In 2009, Juvy joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely S. is from the village of Alindahaw, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 36 years old, and married with four adult-aged children. To make a living, Mely owns and operates a business venture in the transportation sector. The main source of income for the business comes from operating pedicab transport services to local community members. Mely has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Mely joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Mely is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair existing vehicles to provide a better service. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. Mely plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom T., age 35, and her husband, Mr. Sok Sot, age 33, were married in 1990 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. All of them are in school. The family lives along National Road Number five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sreymom has been selling porridge and dessert for 1 year. She buys ingredients to make porridge and dessert by herself and sells in her village. Her husband grows rice; additionally he is a farmer as well. 

Sreymom is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to help purchases motorized hand tiller for her husband to use for farming.

loans.use: To purchase motorized hand tiller.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Lim S., age 30, who lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns a living selling cooking supply from home. Since 2002, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. Beside her current work, she takes time to distill wine and uses the leftover of wine to feed some pigs behind her house. She is married with two children who are secondary students. Her husband sells firewood that he carves them from the forest.
In order to earn extra income, Lim S. will be using the loan to accumulate the quantity of cooking tool to sell.

loans.use: To accumulate the quantity of cooking tool to sell.

loans.name: Sinoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinoun P., 36, and her husband, Mr. San Sang, 29, have been married for over five years. They have two daughters and both of them are still young and stay at home. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sinoun and her husband have been raising pigs and chickens for three years. The couple hopes to expand their business and they just bought seven more piglets and 150 chickens to raise. So, Sinoun is asking for her first loan of $400 to purchase feed for the pigs and chickens.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs and chickens

loans.name: Korina

texts.en:
"Korina S. (0) is a 29-year-old woman living in the town of Savalalo.  She is married and has 1 infant-aged child.  To make a living, Korina is starting a business venture in the food sector making & selling food.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling baked goods in the local community.  Korina has just started operating this business and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Korina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Korina is requesting for the first time a loan from SPBD.    Korina is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  The loan will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Korina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand the borrower's business.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders."

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Leipu

texts.en: Leipu P. (0) is a 37-year-old woman living in the town of Lotofaga Aleipata A. She is married and has four school-aged children. Leipu owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting bananas for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 450 WST a month. Leipu joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Leipu is now requesting a new loan of 1,250 WST which will again be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. The loan will be her 4th from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo K. owns a motorbike which he uses to run a taxi service and is currently earning around US$5 income per day. He uses his income to better meet his family’s living needs. His wife stays at home to sell a few groceries to neighbors and look after for the children. This old couple has given birth to five children who are working in different jobs.

Keo K. is taking out his loan to buy more grocery inventory for his wife to continue selling. The rest of loan will be used to repair his motorcycle that is breaking down frequently.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for his wife's business and to repair his motorcycle

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en:
Mrs. Samnang D. is a 28-year-old mother, and has been married for 6 years. She has two young children, a son and daughter. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Samnang has been fishing for over 10 years. Her boat is old and it breaks down, which disrupts her business. As a result, she is applying for her first loan of $500 to purchase a new boat. The new boat will replace her old one and will allow her to continue her business.

loans.use: Purchase a boat for her fishing business

loans.name: Savan

texts.en:
Mrs. Savan Y., age 48, and her husband, Mr. Sophanna Pol, age 53, were married in 1979 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Three of them married and live outside the family home and one son is a hairdresser. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Savan produces bath mat and sells at her house. Her husband is a soldier. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to connect water from a private water utility service and connect electricity from an electricity utility service to use in her family.

loans.use: To connect water from a private water utility service and connect electricity from an electricity utility service to use in her family.

loans.name: Pao

texts.en:
Pao K. sells cooking supplies out of her home for her neighbors who live in the same village. Another main source of family income comes from her husband’s business: he owns a machine which he uses to provide a battery-charging service in the village.

Pao K. and her husband were married years ago but they do not have a child. Recently, one part of the grocery inventory was exhausted from her stock. Pao K. is therefore applying for a loan to accrue a larger amount of grocery inventory to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Sofarania

texts.en: Sofarania S. (0) is a 47-year-old man living in the town of Utualii. He is married and has eleven adult children. Sofarania owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting bananas for sale. He has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 500 WST a month. Sofarania joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Sofarania is now requesting a new loan of 3,000 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. The loan will be his 6th from SPBD. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. texts.en:

loans.name: Fabiana

texts.en:
Fabiana T. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 67 years old. Fabiana is widowed and has 5 grown-up children. To make a living, Fabiana runs a sari-sari or general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Fabiana has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Fabiana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fabiana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Fabiana is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Fabiana from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Maria has been engaged in this business for more than six years and earns approximately 400 tala a month from these activities.

In 2004, Maria joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 tala from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers like manure. Maria is now requesting a new loan of 1000 tala, which will be used to purchase harvesting equipment. This will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Maria plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

"Mareta M. (0) is a 39-year-old woman living in the town of Tafitoala.  She is married and has 3 infant-aged children.  To make a living, Mareta owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting bananas for sale.  Mareta has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 600 WST a month from these activities.

In 2007, Mareta joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Mareta has successfully repaid a previous loan of $750 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  Mareta is now requesting a new loan of $1000 WST which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  The loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Mareta plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand the borrower's business.

Rosa plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

Vaoa F. works in a family member's business making and selling specialty food products for her community. She is a 28-year-old woman living in the town of Tafitoala. She is married and has three children. Vaoa has been in this business for over four years. From these activities, Vaoa earns approximately 550 WST a month.

Vaoa plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Marjorem

texts.en:
Marjorem B.'s main source of income comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in her community. She is 29 years old, married and has six school-age children. They are from the village of Gingoog, Misamis Oriental. Marjorem has been in this business for over 14 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marjorem joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marjorem has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Marjorem is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita D. is from the village of Romarate in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 67 years old. Anecita is married and has 1 adult children. To make a living, Anecita owns and operates a "sari-sari" or general store where she sells daily use products, such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste etc., in the local community. Anecita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Anecita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Anecita is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be Anecita's fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

In 2009, Sifo joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sifo is requesting her first loan of $1000 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. Sifo plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma O. is from the village of Gingoog in Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Erma is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Erma sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Erma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Erma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Erma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Yum

texts.en:
Mrs. Yum T. (pictured with her son and daughter) is a 51-year-old widow with three sons and two daughters. One of her children is married and lives outside the family home, one daughter is a weaver, and two others attend school. The family live in a small village across Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Yum has been a silk weaver for 29 years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then sells them at Phnom Penh market. Yum is applying for a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase silk materials for her and her son and daughter’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros G. started to expand her hog-fattening business when she joined Kiva partner ASHI in 2007. Although her business was started five years ago, business growth was difficult because her income from selling rice, along with her husband's income, was insufficient to meet the needs of their three children. At that time, her youngest child, who is now 23, had stopped schooling while her second child was in high school and the youngest was in elementary school. Two years ago, her second child also stopped schooling. Despite her children's low level of education because of poverty, a vision of giving her children a better future gave Milagros the courage to join ASHI.

After becoming a member of ASHI, Milagros was able to get a loan for use as additional business capital. She has had two previous loans and is now applying for her third. From her business profits, Milagros was able to pay back her previous loans on time and was also able to meet her family's basic needs. Her future hope is that her business will grow to the extent that she can afford to send her youngest child, currently in school, to college, and support the rest of her children in their own endeavors.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and piglet feed

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Mrs. Phan C., 36, and her husband, Mr. Khom Sor, 35, married in 1994 and have two sons, one of whom attends school. The family live along National Road Number Five, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Since they were married, Phan has been a nail make-up artist and her husband has worked as a fisherman. Phan is requesting her first loan of $600 USD in order to buy a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Bi

texts.en: Bi S., 51, is a domestic farmer. She owns a large piece of farmland that she bought from her neighbor. To earn a living, she plants different kinds of fruits and vegetables with the help of her husband. Bi S. has four daughters, one of whom is married. Three of her daughters are employed as garment workers in Phnom Penh City and contribute their incomes to meeting the family’s living expenses. This coming season, Bi S. hopes to grow crops of potatoes and green beans, but she lacks the money to do so. That is why she has decided to seek a loan from Kiva partner, HKL.

loans.use: To grow potato and green bean crops

loans.name: Ravy

texts.en:
Mr. Ravy C., 43, and his wife, Mrs. Chann Sok, 49, were married in 1991 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of their children attend school and other one stays at home. The family lives along national road number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Ravy has been driving Tuk Tuk taxi for one year. He drives in Phnom Penh. His wife sells yellow cake in front of her house. Yellow cake is a kink of Cambodia cake cooked in steamed Ravy’s Tuk Tuk is old and breaks down very often, so he is applying for his first loan of $800 in order to purchase new a motorbike and a trailer (Tuk Tuk) to replace the old one.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike and a trailer (Tuk Tuk)to replace the old one.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita A. is from the village of Gingoog, Misamis Oriental. She is 53 years old, and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Chheun

texts.en:
Mr. Chheun V., age 36, and his wife, Mrs. Sophea Mom, age 37, have been married since 1995. They have three children, two sons and one daughter. His mother also lives with the family. Their home is approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Chheun and his wife have been farming for 12 years. They sell their products to a middleman who comes to buy at their house. Chheun doesn’t have enough capital for farming, so he is requesting a loan of $300 to help his farming business.

loans.use: To use for farming

loans.name: Pel

texts.en:
The people shown in the picture are Mrs. Pel Y. with her child. Mrs. Pel Y., 26, lives in the province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, about 200 km from Phnom Penh along National Road No. 6.

Pel Y. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop, while her husband works as a local carpenter making wooden beds for sale. This couple has given birth to one lovely kid who is still not in school.

Pel Y. finds that her husband's carpentry business is not a profitable one and she wants her husband to have another good job driving a trailer-taxi. Because she lacks the money, Pel Y. would like a loan of US$700 to buy a trailer motorbike for her husband to begin a taxi service.

loans.use: To buy a trailer motorbike for her husband to begin a taxi service

loans.name: Chetra

texts.en:
Mr. Chetra M., 22 (shown in the picture), and his wife, Mrs. Sreynoch Yun, 19, were married in 2007 and just have a one year old daughter. They live along national road number one apporximetely15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chetra has a motorbike and bicycle repairer for one year, while his wife a scarf weaver for five years. He is able to earn 15,000 riel to 20,000 riel (about 3.75 USD to 5 USD) per day. Now, Chetra is a asking for his first loan of $500 he will use the loan to purchase motorbike and bicycle spare parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike and bicycle spare parts for his motorbike repairing business.

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en: Teymur lives in Baku. This man has his own greenhouse. 10 years ago he started this business. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy the necessary things for improving his greenhouse.

loans.use: to buy the necessary things for improving his greenhouse

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita E. is from the village of Gingoog in Misamis Oriental province. She is fifty years old, married and has three adult-aged children. From her store Carmelita sells seafood, including fish and shrimp, to the local community. Carmelita has been in business for over twenty years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Carmelita joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Carmelita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase new products for her store. This will be Carmelita’s first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use all profits to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her store's range of offerings

loans.name: Pho

texts.en:
Mrs. Pho Y., 52, is a widow with two sons and two daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home. One son is employed full-time, and one daughter operates a grocery store out of the family’s home. The family lives along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Pho has been producing baysey for twenty years. Baysey is a kind of Khmer sacrificial item made of a section of banana tree trunk set on legs. Three, five, seven or nine layers of banana leaves rolled up into finger shapes are attached.

Pho is asking for $300 (her first loan) to help purchase more stock for her daughter’s grocery for Pchum Ben, an upcoming Khmer festival during which food is offered to Buddhist monks in the hope that such a deed will benefit the spirits of dead relatives.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her daughter's grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock to expand his store's offerings

loans.name: Tharath's Group

texts.en: Mr. Tharath S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers who live in Slab Ta Aon Village in Kandal Province. He is a chicken breeder. Since his chicken business is doing well, he wants to expand it by purchasing more chickens for breeding. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living with this loan. His wife, Mrs. Chea Pheach, is a housewife who takes care of their children. Mr. Tharath S. is 27 years old and the father of two young children.

loans.use: Purchasing more chickens for breeding.

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha M., 35, and her husband, Mr. Visalsok Sin, 38, were married in 1993 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of their children attend school and other one stays at home. Besides of her children, Chantha also has her old mother is living with her.

Chantha has been raising pigs for over 10 years, while her husband has been a photographer for 8 years.  Chantha is asking for her first loan of $1,000 she will use the loan to replace a camera for her husband and buy 10 more piglets and feed for pigs for her raising pigs business.

loans.use: To replace a camera for her husband and buy 10 more piglets and feed for pigs for her raising pigs business.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: P. makes rattan furniture. She is 29 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, which is located about 200 km from the capital, Phnom Penh. She has two teenage children. She works hard every day to earn income. P. takes time two or three days each week to weave a set of rattan cupboards, which she sells when she is done. Her husband, who is a local fisherman, helps her to transport the finished products to customers' houses. P. also grows crops on her farm each year. She will use her loan as capital to plant various crops.

loans.use: To plant various crops

loans.name: Sevda

texts.en: Sevda applyes to Kiva for the second loan. Having improved her business she started the cement sales. Now she needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy the building materials for improving her business.

loans.use: to buy the building materials

loans.name: Mrs. Kim Soeun Chev Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group consists of fifteen people. It is located in AnD. Village in Kandal Province. All of the members will use their parts of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Kim SoeU. C. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she grows rice to to earn a living. She faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil that damages her crops. In order to deal with this problem, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field and to make her crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. MoeU. Thy, is a fisherman. Mrs. Kim SoeU. C. is 32 years old and the mother of two young children. 

Four members in this group loans have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows tH. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en:
Making furniture is a main part of 45-year-old S.’s daily routine. S. and her husband currently buy raw materials to make rattan cupboards to sell in bulk to their customers, who come directly to their house to buy. They also buy furniture from other weavers at a reasonable price and resell them to gain extra profits. They have done this since 2002.

S. is modest mother who has five children: one is single and the others are married and have ready started new homes. All five of her children also help make cupboards. S. is looking for a loan to sustain her business growth.

loans.use: To sustain her business growth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new motor-bike

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en: Ludmila is married and has two adult sons. She sells clothing at the local open market. Ludmila has been in this business for 10 years. Large experience helps her to choose the right goods that sell well. Ludmila would like to borrow 17,000 UAH to purchase inventories for the fall. Ludmila enjoys being in sales and dreams to open a small shop in her town.

loans.use: to purchase inventories for the fall

loans.name: Sophoin

texts.en:
Mr. Sophoin N. is 47 years old. His wife, Mrs. Nhor San, is 48 years old. They live along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1982 and have five children, three sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside of the family house, one son is an electrician, and another one is a garment factory worker. 

Sophoin has been farming for thirty years. He grows rice. His wife has been selling vegetables for twelve years. She buys the vegetables from villagers to sell in the Derm Kor market in Phnom Penh. 

Sophoin took his first loan from Kiva through Maxima. Now he is applying for his second loan of $1,000 to purchase wooden materials to build a house where he lives.

loans.use: To purchase wooden materials

loans.name: Mrs. Sarong Chhon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people who are all living in Andoung village in Kandal province is made up the village bank loan. Mrs. Sarong C. is a village bank president who has been selected the members and they all will use the loan indifferent purposes. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Aside from this business, she is also a pig breeding. Since her breeding pigs business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Lorn Khorn, is a farmer who owns 1-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Sarong C. is 52 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are woodworkers. 

Four members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Purchasing more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Sela

texts.en:
Mr. Sela S., age 18, is single.  He lives with his widowed mother, a garment factory worker, in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sela has been a construction worker for seven months. He doesn’t have his own transportation, so he spends a lot of money on traveling costs. Because of this, he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle so he can commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Mrs. Kunthea Than Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of 18 people who all live in Ta Reab Doun Sar village in Kandal province. Mrs. Kunthea T. has been selected by the members of the group to be its president. She sells fish in the local market. Her husband, Mr. P. Phearak, is a fisherman whose boat is broken. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still don't earn enough income to support their family’s needs. Because of this, Mrs. Kunthea T. is asking for a loan to buy more fishnets, fix her husband's boat, and repair her family's house. She is 24 years old and the mother of two children who are only ages one and three.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets, fix her husband's boat, and repair her family's house.

loans.name: Yetunde

texts.en: Yetunde sells provisions and drinks to make a living. She is very determined to expand her business and to maximize her profits. Yetunde is 43 years old and married with 6 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhary Net Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twenty-one people living in Ta Reab Doun S. village in Kandal province have formed a village bank loan group.  Each member will use part of the loan for his or her own purposes.  Mrs. Sokhary N. has been selected by the group's members to be its president. She is a housewife. Her husband, Mr. HE. Kimheang, is employed in a factory. Since his workplace is far from their house, he has difficulty getting there. Thus, Mrs. Sokhary N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband. She hopes to save some money from hiring taxis. Mrs. S. Savy, a group guarantor, is also presented in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband.

loans.name: Arif

texts.en:
Arif was born in 1972. He is single. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Kalbadjar, and is now settled in Khirdalan.

Arif has sold bath accessories for 10 years. He is requesting a loan of 2000 Azerbaijani manat (or about $2500 US) to buy additional accessories.

loans.use: to buy bath accessories

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Mrs. Nget S. lives in Chek Village in Kandal Province. She sells vegetables in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Heang Sokchea, is a farmer who cultivates rice on land he owns. He faces difficulties on his farm, because he does not have much money to spend on his rice paddy. Thus, Mrs. Nget S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline to fuel a water pump for the rice field. She is 40 years old and the mother of four children. Three of the children are enrolled in the local school, while the youngest child is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline to fuel a water pump for the rice field

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: fonds de rouleemnt

loans.name: Orn

texts.en: Mrs. Orn L. lives in the village of Ank in the province of Kandal. She is a dessert seller. Her husband, Mr. Phun Touch, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he cultivates rice. For this plantation, he needs money to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and hire laborers to work on the field. Thus, Mrs. Orn L. decided to ask for a loan for her husband’s business. She is 58 years old and the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthy M. is a villager in Vihear in the province of Kandal. She is a fish seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Sal Srorn, is a fisherman. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn insufficient income to support their family living. In order to improve their living standard, Mrs. Chanthy M. decided to request a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike, so that her husband can work as a motorbike taxi driver. She is 28 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria sells provisions, drinks and clothes in her shop. She is very happy with the growing nature of her business. Maria is a mother of 3 children and she is 34 years old. she is very optimistic about the growth of her business and the prosperity of her family. She is requesting for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more drinks, clothes and provisions to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and clothes to sell

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: The people shown in the picture above are Chim N. and her husband. Chim N. raises a few pigs in a stall next to her house to earn a living. Additionally, she goes to the forest to collect burnable oil from trees and turns it into glue to sell (it is used in furniture making). Her husband works with her in collecting glue. This older couple married years ago and has six children. Two of their children are employed in different occupations. Chim N. is taking out her loan to buy a piglet to breed, and the rest to buy more tools for scraping glue.

loans.use: To buy a piglet and tools for scraping glue.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Mrs. Horn C. was born in 1970 and she now lives in the village of Rokar in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Sun Vichet, is a fisherman. Now Mrs. Horn C. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and some nets for fishing. She hopes to increase income and improve the family's lives with this loan. She has four children, two of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband and children are shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and some fishing nets.

loans.name: Bisi

texts.en: Bisi sells shoes and bags to make a living in Lagos state, Nigeria. She loves this business because it is highly competitive. Bisi is 35 years old and married with 3 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags

loans.name: Savonn

texts.en: Mrs. Savonn V. is 39 years old and she lives in Chek village in Kandal province. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Chea Sal, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He faces an problem because he does not have enough money to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, gasoline, and hire laborers to work on the field. Thus, Mrs. Savonn V. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She has five children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of picture.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, gasoline, and hire laborers to work on the field.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor M. is 29 years old, married and the mother of one young child who is already enrolled in primary school. She contributes to her family by working as a garment worker for a factory, while her husband works as a construction foreman in the village. The family finds it hard to travel to work or anywhere else, because they don’t have their own vehicle for their family’s driving requirements. Sor M. hopes to buy a new motorcycle but her personal savings are still not sufficient. She is therefore requesting a loan to add to her little savings in order to buy a new motorcycle which she will use to transport her family. She and her husband are pictured at their house.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Rukayat

texts.en: Rukayat is very optimistic about the speedy growth of her business, and she has the zeal to pull her family out of poverty. Rukayat sells hair extensions and she is also a hair stylist. She is 26 years old and married with a child. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva Lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Tha

texts.en: Mrs. Tha S. lives in Preak Ta Ke village in Kandal province. She is a second-hand clothes seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more clothes. She would use the rest of money to add to her savings to buy a motorbike to transport the clothes to sell. She is a 45-year-old widow with five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is happily married with 4 children and she is 30 years old. Mary sells crates of drinks and she also sells cooked food in her shop. Mary hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more crates of drinks and foodstuffs. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks and foodstuffs

loans.name: Chann

texts.en: Mrs. Chann S., age 30, sells fish that she and her husband purchase from wholesale suppliers and other fishermen. She buys the fish on credit and repays the debt after she sells the fish. She starts her business in the late morning and finishes during the evening with much income. In addition, her husband also uses his motorcycle to run a taxi service for a fee. Chann S. lives with two children who attend school and are dependent on her. Chann S. will be using the loan to buy a plot of farmland in a good location for basic farming. She will rent it out to a farmer for a fee, and she proposes to plant crops on it in the future.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland in a good location for basic farming

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace sells foodstuffs to make a living. Grace has nine children. She is 57 years old, and she is a widow. She hopes for the loan amount of 150,000 NGN in order to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kham

texts.en:
Kham P., 41, is a busy woman who attempts to earn money from many ventures. She cultivates rice as well as buying it in bulk from other farmers to store in her home. She buys when rice is commanding the lowest price and then sells it to gain income. As an extra profit, her husband works in construction.

Kham P. is a good mother who has given birth to six children. Four of her children are single and under her care, while the other two are married and live separately.

Kham P. is applying for a loan to buy a used motorbike which she will use to reduce the cost of her family's transportation.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for family transportation

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer sells jewelry. This business is her only source of income and she hopes to make profits. She is 33 years old and married with three children.

Jennifer hopes for the loan of N140,000 to purchase more jewelry to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry to sell

loans.name: Muminiso

texts.en: B. Muminiso is a 38-year-old woman. She is married and is the loving mother of five children. Muminiso is a market vendor. For the last thirteen years she has been selling cottonseed oil at the local market. In the traditional Tajik cuisine the majority of the meals are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil, especially our national dish, “Pilau”, which needs a lot of cottonseed oil in order to make it delicious. So the goods that Muminiso is selling are in popular demand among the population. Today, Muminiso is planning to increase her business. For this reason she requests 4,500 Somoni. She is counting on your help and thanks you for your support. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cottonseed oil to sell

loans.name: Lam

texts.en:
There are many Cambodians who make a living as rice cultivators; one of them is Mrs. Lam O. who has been working in this sector since 1979. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland that they inherited from their grandparents. From this business they can generated much income. In addition, her husband has a job as a domestic building worker.

This humble couple is blessed with six children: three are married, while the other three are single.

Lam O.'s husband has complained to her that it is hard for him to travel to work because he does not have his own vehicle. To solve the problem, Lam O. would like a loan to purchase an old motorcycle to make it easier for her husband to commute to his workplace.

loans.use: To purchase an old motorcycle for her husband's commute

loans.name: Papa Alassane

texts.fr: Papa Alassane D. est un commerçant de pièces détachées auto derrière la gare routière de Mbour ville située à 80km de Dakar la capitale sénégalaise. Il est âgé de 36 ans et marié, il sollicite ce prêt pour faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle  qui de plus en plus demande  les pièces de nouvelles marques de véhicules. Les crédits obtenus successivement de l UIMCEC lui ont permis de démarrer une petite activité de vente de pièces détachées. Les revenus tirés du commerce lui permettent de développer son commerce mais aussi ainsi subvenir à ses dépenses quotidiennes

loans.use: achat de marcahndises

loans.name: Folajomi

texts.en:
Folajomi sells building materials like window frames, glass, nails, planks and house paint. She is 30 years old and married with a child. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria.

Folajomi is requesting the loan of N140,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta T. (0) is a 40-year-old woman living in the town of Lano. She is married and has four school-aged children. Eseta owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 200 WST a month. In 2008, Eseta joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Eseta is now requesting a new loan of 1,000 WST which will again be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. The loan will be her 2nd from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Rahimakhon

texts.en:
Rahimakhon is a widow and the mother of four children. Her women’s clothing business has been a valuable source of income for her family over the past 15 years that she’s been in business. Rahimakhon is hardworking, polite and a communicative entrepreneur. She has a focus on service and loves being able to help women with their clothing needs. Rahimakhon has requested a loan of $1000 US to purchase new inventory. This loan will help her to continue developing her business and provide a good income for her children.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase new women's clothing for the spring season

loans.name: Uch

texts.en:
Cultivating rice is part of 47-year-old Uch H.’s daily routine. Rice is an essential product, vital to Cambodian people. She learned to cultivate rice from her grandmother and she has been very widely known in this sector since she was single. She has since divorced her husband.

Uch H. never wastes time. She works hard everyday in order to generate a daily income to ensure her children will attend the highest level of education. Two of her children are employed and have provided their income to support their family's food needs a little more.

Uch H. will be using her loan to buy piglets to raise for additional profit. With the remainder of loan she will buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
Since he was young, Akram has known how to work. His parents taught him how to get by as an agriculturist, and he learned very well. Now that he is the father of a family, he still works as an agriculturalist. Thanks to his parents, Akram now has the opportunity to move forward as a farmer, and he hopes to increase his agricultural production so that he can give his loved ones a better life.

Despite being a good agriculturalist and worker, he needs help to move forward and improve his production. This is why he is asking for a loan, so that he can buy more of the seeds and fertilizers he needs, which are very expensive, but without them his production will not improve. You can help Akram keep moving forward with his development plans.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Kamardin

texts.en: M. Kamardin is 35 years old, is married, and has four children. The last five years of his life he has devoted to agricultural work and on market days he brings his products to the market. For Kamardin the harvest is what he enjoys the most and he devotes a lot of time to sorting the melons and watermelons that he will sell because the price will depend on their size. Agriculture is full of satisfaction for him and his family - even more when the produce sells for a good price at the market. That is his motivation to continue planting. This is the second loan that Kamardin has with IMON International, having made his payments on time for his first loan. With the money requested he will buy seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for his farm. Kamardin is very grateful to those who support him because they allow him to provide well-being to his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Mirzomahmad

texts.en: M. Mirzomahmad, 50, is a farmer. He is very experienced in this business as he has been farming since 2003. He is married with six children and his elder son and wife help him with the business. Unfortunately Mirzomahmad's farmland is infertile, so he is in need of a loan in the amount of 3,000 Somoni to purchase seeds and fertilizer to use on his crop. He hopes the loan will allow him to increase his crop above and beyond what it was in previous years. As for his future plan, Mirzomahmad wants all of his children to go to university and to get good jobs. Be an important part of the well-being of this humble family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C.
