loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn A. is a 36-year-old mother and a rice grower. She has two children, who are her inspiration to work hard. Her dream is that some day she will have a well-established business which would provide all the funds she needs to pay for her children's college education. Roselyn started her business in 1990 and she says that her investment has been tears, sweat, hard work, patience and a small amount of savings. She maintains that it has been worth it because her rice farm income has been very helpful in meeting her family's daily needs.

Roselyn plans to buy fertilizers and seeds with her loan of 15,000 PHP, making it truly worthwhile. She is hopeful for a better yield this time, especially since her children's needs are growing in number. Roselyn says that she likes CEVI's services because it charges the lowest interest rate, currently 2 per cent a month, making a loan very affordable to repay.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Khvoeuy

texts.en: S. L. is 45 years old and a resident of the Kompong Tom province, Cambodia. She makes a living raising pigs, which she sells for slaughter in four months time after raising them. She has been raising pigs for about years and is currentL. earning around $4 a day. S. L. is married with two children, all two of whom are students in the secondary school. Her husband, Kong, is 48 years old. He sells wood carvings by cutting the wood from the forest. S. L. is applying for a loan as capital to allow her husband to purchase a wheelbarrow to serve as his wood carving transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a wheelbarrow to serve as his wood carving transportation

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera is a member of the KDC borrower group in Kiboriloni, Iringa, She is 45 year old woman,she is widowed and a mother of 8 children. Her children are 30,28,25,23,21,20,17,12 years old.

Vera has owned shoes business for 20 years, She works 12 hours a day and earns monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Vera`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy  more shoes for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Vera hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for sale

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina Z. is from the village of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Rosalina owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling a variety of products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In May 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand the business and support the education of her children.

loans.name: Horm

texts.en:
C. currently makes rattan furniture. She is 31 years old and is a resident of Kompong Tom province, located about 200 km from the capital, Phnom Penh. She has two children, both of whom are teenagers and attend school.

C. saves up over ten sets of rattan and then sells them to her buyers for profit. Generally, her valued clients need to order a few days or a week in advance.

Another source of family income comes from her husband driving a motor taxi. C. requests a loan to allow her husband to buy a trailer to connect with his existing motorcycle which will enable him to pick up more customers.

loans.use: To buy a trailer for her husband's existing motorcycle

loans.name: Elimenesi

texts.en:
Elimenesi is a member of the Msagara borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro, She is 42 years old woman,She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 15,13,11,and 9 years old .

Elimenesi has owned crops business for 6 years,She works 12hours a day and earns monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Elimenesi`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more crops like maize.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,ELimenesi hopes to save more money, get more food for her family  and expand her business

loans.use: To buy more cros for sale

loans.name: Prescila

texts.en:
Prescila M. is from the town of Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old, and married with six adult-aged children. To make a living, Prescila owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling green bananas in the local community. Prescila has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In May 2009, Prescila joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Prescila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business and supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou Tessara, a 26-year-old mother, is a pig grower. She has two children, the eldest being 6 years old, and both are studying in school.

Marilou dreams that someday she will have a larger piggery business where she can raise more pigs and earn the funds she needs to pay for her children’s education and daily costs at home.

Marilou started her business in 2004. Aside from pigs, she also sells banana crackers and earns Php 6,000 a month by being a seller.

Receiving a loan of Php 8,000 is truly worthwhile because Marilou plans to buy piglets and pig feed. She is very optimistic that her business will grow and wishes to earn a better income for her family.

Marilou said that she likes the services of CEVI because they give the lowest interest rate, which is 2% a month and is very affordable to repay.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Keal

texts.en: Keal P., 52, has a lot of experience in making rattan furniture.  She produces and sells her furniture to traders directly from her family home. She typically generates around $5 USD a day from her business and shares her income to meet her family’s needs. She is married to Eoun, 55, who is a local carpenter. Four of their children are married and the other two are school-age children. Keal P. would like a loan for business capital. She will use half of the loan for her husband as an investment in his carpentry business, and with the rest of loan she will buy more raw materials to make furniture.

loans.use: For carpentry and furniture making

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth V. business is a rice grower. She tills a hectare of farm so closely from their house. Aside from farm, she also raises pigs. She feeds and bathes them everyday to be able to grow her pigs healthy and heavy.  She has four children. Her eldest child is 24 years old and is still living with her.
Receiving a loan of Php 8,000 is truly worthwhile because she needs resources for farm financing. The seeds that she used in her farm are not yet paid , the loan will help paying the seeds. She also planned buying 2 piglets and feed. She said that CEVI gives the lowest interest rate, which is 2% a month, and is very affordable to repay

loans.use: rice seeds

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a member of Msagara borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro, She is 48 year old woman. She is married and a mother of 6 children. Her children are 27,23,19,12,14,16 years old. 

Florence has owned fruits business for 5 years, She works 12 hours a day and earns monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Florence`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,She requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Florance hopes to save more money, get more food for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fruits

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma Z., 60, is from the village of San Isidro, Medina Misamis Oriental. She is married and has six adult children. Thelma owns a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of products like vinegar and soy sauce. Thelma has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In June 2009, Thelma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thelma is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Thelma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria T. has no family but she has a very promising business, which is rice.  She is 49 years old and is growing rice since 1986. For 22 years, she managed to keep all her earnings to save money for future use. 
“ I own 2 hectares of farm. Every year I can plant three times and harvest 100 sacks per hectare. I also raise pigs”, she said.

But now, she needs a loan to buy fertilizers and piglets. She wanted her business to prosper to be able to hire more workers and employ more un-employed people in their location.

loans.use: farm financing and piglets

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem E. raises at least two lot of pig a season from her home to earn a living. She, 48, is the determined mother who tries to earn money in order to ensure her five children to obtain the highest educations. Her husband’s name is Ngoun Touch, 49 years old taxi driver. Additionally, she will be using this loan as capital to buy a cow which allows to her husband uses to pick up carving wood from the forest to sell. Sem E. was not available taking photo so her son appears in the picture instead.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Melly

texts.en:
Melly Rosillo, 42 years old, mother of five children from Surallah South Cotabato City.. Her eldest child is 23 years old and her dreams for all her children are to have a good, healthy life and to be responsible persons always in everything that they do.

She is asking a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farming materials and pay the laborers who helped prepare the lands. 

Now, she is hoping that with her decision to loan for farm financing, she will reap a good return of investment and she is happy because her loan has only 2% interest rate.

loans.use: farm financing and payment for the laborer

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma T., a 44-year-old mother of three children, is also a rice grower.  For 23 years she has worked hard tilling her field under the heat of the sun.  She has never lost hope that someday she will be able to achieve her dream of sending all of her children to college, and to have an established business so that her family can live happily.

She is asking for a loan of 8,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc.  She will use the loan to pay the laborers who help prepare the land and also to start a new business.

She says that she likes CEVI services because they offer very low interest rate loans as well as insurance coverage to all their borrowers.

loans.use: to pay the laborers

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica B. grows pigs. Currently in her barn she has two pigs that she feeds and bathes every day. She likes pigs a lot. She said that when she was just a little girl, her mother scolded her because she always played with the piglets at the back of their house. That is why it became her business which she started in 2006.

Jessica would like to ask for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy more piglets and pig feed. Surely, the loan will help a lot to ensure her business growth.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie S., 55 years old is a rice and corn grower. She has three children. Her eldest is 34 and all her children are now living separately. She was a CEVI client since 2000. She likes its services especially that it offers a very lo interest rate of 2% a month.

She wanted to grow her business. Receiving a loan therefore is very worthwhile since she was not able to pay yet the laborers who work for land preparation. She will also invest some of the money to other business ventures.

She likes CEVI services a lot a she said that she will not quit joining the program because it truly beneficial for her business growth.

loans.use: to pay the farm laborers

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita M., 57 years old, is a basic storeowner.  She sells snacks item, rice, sardines, canned goods, and other basic needs of the people living in their village. She started selling since 2008. And aside from store, she also own a farm, which is 1-hectare in size that she keeps productive to be able to support the growing needs in their family. She has one child that is 20 years old now. Her dreams for her child is are able to graduate in college and pursue a high paying job. She also wished that her child would grow as a responsible person in the future.

She needs a loan of Php 15,000 to finance her business. She will buy additional merchandise to attract more customers and maximize her sales. She is hopeful that she will reap a good return of all her investments.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia O. is a rice farmer. For 30 years she has been helping her husband till their 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) farm. The income she gets from her farm is used for family consumption. When there is an excess of rice, they sell it to their friends for additional income for the family.

Eufemia has requested a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to buy farming materials as well as to pay the laborers who help maintain and prepare the land.

Eufemia is very optimistic that she will be able to achieve a maximum harvest. In that way, her dream of buying more farms will be easily achieved. She chose CEVI because, aside from the fact that they give the lowest interest rate, they also bring education to people.

loans.use: To buy farming materials and to pay laborers

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en:
Chorn S. is a 39-year-old farmer and married woman. She currently lives in her own small home located in the rural area of Kompong Tom Province. She has been living with other members and managing the farming business since 1979. Chorn S. is married with three single children who are dependent on her income. Her husband helps sustain the family by working as an ox-trader. He always buys cows at reasonable prices from people who live far away, and he sells those cows to bring in income.

loans.name: Mylenne

Mylenne has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Mylenne is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Mylenne from GDMPC. loans.name: Esther Wairimu

texts.en:
Esther Wairimu M. is fifty two years old and married to  fifty-seven year old Jonathan M.. They have  a twenty five year old daughter named Mary Wambui M..

Esther has been selling African attire for five years now. She has no loans from othe MFIs and was introduced to KADET by existing members. She intends to use the loan to buy more stock to sell.
The client's area of business is densely populated and she relies on foreign customers to buy her clothes. With the extra profits generated from the increase in stock, Esther intends to open a big shop so that she can make the clothes she sells instead of purchasing them from wholesalers.

Esther believes she is hardworking and determined and her hopes and dreams are to be supplying in East African Market.

 ABOUT KADET LTD. 

Kadet Ltd is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya that was formed in 2000 to offer access to financial services to the rural communities through the microfinance model. Kadet is the only microfinance in Kenya with a strong rural presence and a genuine concern for the welfare of children and the communities we serve. As a member of the Association of Microfinance Institutions in Kenya, Kadet has continued to empower communities by providing access to easy-to-pay loans. Loan products available at the MFI are designed to offer solutions to challenges facing communities in these rural habitations. Obtain more information on Kadet from the press section of the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The client intends to use the whole amount of loan to increase the stock of African Attire as the demand is high.

loans.name: Diosdada

This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Diosdada from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Salina Chebet

texts.en:
Salina Chebet is 36 years old and married to a farmer. She is blessed with three little children. Her cereal business is located in Moiben. She supplies the cereals to institutions, which are her major customers.

She has been in this cereal business for the past three years. With the loan she is taking from KADET she plans to add more stock which includes beans. In future she intends to grow her business and be able to purchase more cereals so that she can supply it to many other institutions.

Salina Chebet S. was introduced to KADET by a previous borrower.

loans.name: Abdurauf

texts.en:
Cattle are raised in order to be butchered, to obtain derived products, as well as to be used for agricultural tasks. Abdurauf has been dedicated to cattle farming for three years. He started this business as a young man, with his father's support. His wife (pictured) actively helps him with operations. Abdurauf makes a great effort in order to meet the needs of his family and to bring sustenance to his humble home. His greatest need now is to buy young cattle for expanding his business. For this reason, Abdurauf turned to IMON International in order to obtain loans that will allow him to purchase these animals and make his business advance.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells foodstuffs and drinks to make a living. She is 40 years old and she is happily married. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support in this crucial time.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Grace Kwamboka

texts.en:
Grace is forty-nine years old and married to Evans Ototo, who is fifty-five years old. They have five children, named Stella Nyambane - twenty-four years old, Monica Nyamusi - twenty-one years old, Juliet Kemunto -nineteen years old, Jackson Mambe - fifteen years old and Christine Gesale - nine years old.

The client has been in the quarry business for two and a half years. She was introduced to the Kiva field partner, KADET, by other existing clients, and she has no loans from other MFIs. She intends to use the loan to rent another site and hire more miners.

Grace's place of business is Njiru - an upcoming market center in a semi-slum area.

With the extra profit, she intends to pay school fees for her children. Grace works hard and her hopes and dreams are to see all her children go through school successfully.

 ABOUT KADET LTD. 

Kadet Ltd is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya that was formed in 2000 to offer access to financial services to the rural communities through the microfinance model. Kadet is the only microfinance in Kenya with a strong rural presence and a genuine concern for the welfare of children and the communities we serve. As a member of the Association of Microfinance Institutions in Kenya, Kadet has continued to empower communities by providing access to easy-to-pay loans. Loan products available at the MFI are designed to offer solutions to challenges facing communities in these rural habitations. Obtain more information on Kadet from the press section of the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To rent another site and hire more miners.

loans.name: Ahmadjon

texts.en:
H. Ahmadjon is from the district of Kostakoz, Tajikistan. Currently, he dedicates himself to his livestock business, a popular enterprise that is characteristic of the region. He is the father of three children whom he cares for and has the responsibility of educating. His wife (pictured) actively helps him with operations. It’s important to note that Ahmadjon is very conscious of his duty to support his family financially. It’s for this reason that he turned to IMON International to obtain a loan to purchase some pregnant cows to help him increase his income. With your help, Ahmadjon will be able to make his business succeed and support his family. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Josephine Jerop

texts.en:
Josephine  is thirty five years old and married to Simon Kibor. They have four children, named Purity Chepkoror -twelve years, Valerine Chepchumba -nine years, Shoney Ruto -seven years and Daryl Kipkemboi - four and half years.

The client has been in the selling clothes business for one year. She was introduced to KADET through other existing clients and she has no loan from other MFI's.

Josephine gets clothes from an open air market and supplies to her customers in their houses and places of work. She intends to use the loan to increase her stock of sweaters, duvettes and ladies blouses as the profit margin is wide for these products.

With the extra profit, the client intends to develop the piece of land she had acquired two years ago. Josephine believes that she is hardworking and innovative. Her hopes and dreams are to expand the business so that she can be stable in the business and increase her income so as to improve the living standards of her family.

loans.name: Andrea Fely

texts.en:
Andrea lives in Barangay, Centro 1 of Angadanan, Isabela. She manages a general store in the village. She is thirty-two years old and married to Jupiter D. C., who manages a tricycle transport in their village. The couple has one daughter named Jherry Ann Faith, who is four years old. 

Andrea has managed her store for about a year, and according to her, she is generating an average net income of $30 weekly that is invested in the business. Sometimes, she also saves a small amount for the future education of their daughter and future children. She is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders and she hopes that they will allow her to borrow PHP6,000 that will serve as additional business capital. She is very patient and industrious in managing her business even though she is now pregnant.

loans.use: Additional capital
